Up and coming events

This month two fantastic summer shows open at the Barbican in London - the first of which, 'The Surreal House', explores the power and mystery of the house in our collective imagination (Thumbnail credit OMA, Villa Dall'Ava, 1991)

Graduate Fashion Week

By James Bithell

MUSE's fashion team take a look at some of Britain's best graduate fashion at Earl's Court this June. GFW has already launched the careers of Stella McCartney, Christopher Bailey and Preen's Justin Thornton ... can you spot a new star here?

Sofia Redgrave

I hit the Whistles sale this weekend, and although there was a wealth of beautiful ruched silk dresses, well cut trousers and stylish t-shirts all hanging on the sale rack with at least 50% off their price, their lure was curtailed by something much more interesting: the new pre-fall collection

Frank Gardner

By James Bithell

As a BBC security correspondent, one is expected to put themselves in the firing line. Liv Evans and Mia de Graaf speak to someone willing to do anything for the story

A doll's life: a choice or a consequence?

By James Bithell

Will it ever be acceptable for little girls to dream of being pole dancers? Richard Lemmer talks to the York Pole Exercise Club and Natasha Walter, author of Living Dolls: The Return of Sexism about the line between degregation and liberation

Should private ownership be a public issue?

Britain has some of the strongest gun legislation in the world. Ben Gascoyne asks whether laws designed to protect the public have gone too far?

Fresh out of Asia

By James Bithell

Camilla Apcar talks to the organiser of the Elephant Parade in London about wildlife, charity and vandalism

Beauty and the beast

The bikini round may no longer be an essential part of entering beauty pageants, but will they ever be about more than appearances? Kate Goligher investigates

Henry James Foy

Ladies and Gentlemen of the class of 2012. Enjoy the freedom and opportunities of University life. Oh, never mind; you will not understand the freedom and opportunities of University until you're mired in third-year hell (Thumbnail credit Justyn Hardcastle)

Social pariah: Charlotte Hogarth-Jones

Friday night - Duchess. I have not been out for a long, long time

So-called life: Liam O'Brien

While thinking (admittedly for about five minutes, with a Corona in hand) about my last column in Nouse, I have come to reflect upon just how big a part Pokemon played in my childhood

Wimbledon by numbers

Wimbledon by numbers

MUSE: 22 June 2010

While I would usually attempt to fill this space with an amusing story about production, I seem to be struggling this edition. The funny has run out, some would say. I can only put this down to the fact that it's the last paper of the year and, as much as I try and deny it, it seems like a watershed in my NOUSE career (Thumbnail credit George Lowther)

By James Bithell

Going through the Mil: Modern Literature

f someone, under the age of 75 and living in the West, were to say to me- "Twilight? Never heard of it," I think I'd kiss them, while weeping with joy, before the heart attack could cut me off
